abstract: Stocks tumbled Friday in one of their sharpest declines this year, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average firmly below 10,000, as a disappointing jobs report cast a pall over the nation’s economic recovery, The New York Times reported.
snippet: Stocks tumbled Friday in one of their sharpest declines this year, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average firmly below 10,000, as a disappointing jobs report cast a pall over the nation’s economic recovery, The New York Times reported.
lead_paragraph: Stocks tumbled Friday in one of their sharpest declines this year, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average firmly below 10,000, as a disappointing jobs report cast a pall over the nation’s economic recovery, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser reported.

headline.main: U.S. Indexes Fall Sharply on Jobs Data

abstract: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission issued a subpoena to Goldman Sachs on Monday for “failing to comply with a request for documents and interviews in a timely manner.”
snippet: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission issued a subpoena to Goldman Sachs on Monday for “failing to comply with a request for documents and interviews in a timely manner.”
lead_paragraph: 6:15 p.m. | Updated The commission investigating the causes of the financial crisis said Monday that it had subpoenaed Goldman Sachs and harshly accused the investment bank of trying to delay and disrupt its inquiry, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline.main: Goldman Gets Subpoena From Financial Crisis Panel

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission accused the mortgage lender of collecting outsize fees from about 200,000 borrowers facing foreclosure.
snippet: The Federal Trade Commission accused the mortgage lender of collecting outsize fees from about 200,000 borrowers facing foreclosure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Countrywide Home Loans and its mortgage servicing unit, which are now part of Bank of America, agreed on Monday to pay $108 million to settle federal charges that the company overcharged customers who were struggling to hang onto their homes.

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said two Countrywide Financial mortgage-servicing companies had agreed to pay $108 million to settle charges that they collected excessive mortgage-servicing fees.
snippet: The Federal Trade Commission said two Countrywide Financial mortgage-servicing companies had agreed to pay $108 million to settle charges that they collected excessive mortgage-servicing fees.
lead_paragraph: 1:27 p.m. | Updated The Federal Trade Commission announced Monday that two Countrywide Financial mortgage-servicing companies had agreed to pay $108 million to settle charges that they collected excessive mortgage-servicing fees from financially troubled homeowners, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

headline.main: Countrywide to Pay $108 Million to Settle F.T.C. Case

abstract: Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, cut his price target for Bank of America’s stock, saying the bank faced “serious challenges” from multiple sources. But he kept his “buy” rating for the stock.
snippet: Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, cut his price target for Bank of America’s stock, saying the bank faced “serious challenges” from multiple sources. But he kept his “buy” rating for the stock.
lead_paragraph: Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, cut his price target for Bank of America on Monday to $22.80 a share from $27.50, saying the bank faced “serious challenges” from multiple sources.

headline.main: Bove Cuts His Price Target for Bank of America Stock
